block.p: U.S. Sees an Opportunity In Split Among Insurgents American and Iraqi officials believe the recent violent clashes between Iraqi insurgents and Al Qaeda present them with one of the biggest opportunities since the insurgency began, and they have begun talking with local insurgents, hoping to enlist them to cooperate with them against the terrorist group.

Swiss Paper Leak Investigated Switzerland has begun criminal investigations to track down the source of a leak to the Zurich-based newspaper SonntagsBlick of what it reported was a secret document referring to clandestine C.I.A. prisons in Eastern Europe.

Iran and Europe at Odds After Iran moved to break the internationally monitored seals on its nuclear facilities, a contest of wills between Iran and its adversaries unfolded, with the Europeans threatening to refer Iran to the United Nations Security Council for possible punitive actions and Iran issuing defiant new warnings.

Norway Pounds at Glass Ceiling Norway's leftist government put into effect one of the more radical attempts to achieve sexual equality: requiring that 40 percent of the board members of the nation's large, publicly traded private companies be women.

Turkish Flu Response Criticized International experts said that while Turkish officials were taking appropriate measures, their initial slow response to outbreaks of avian influenza have created a health crisis that may be difficult to remedy.

Global Warming as a Frog Killer Scientists studying a fast-dwindling genus of colorful harlequin frogs on misty mountainsides in Central and South America report that global warming is combining with a spreading fungus to kill off many species. But experts on amphibian disease and ecology are divided over the finding, which is being published today in the journal Nature.

Israel Ends Talks With Preacher Israel said it was breaking off negotiations on a tourism project with the evangelical leader Pat Robertson, left, in response to his remarks suggesting that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's stroke was divine retribution.

Chinese Respond to Toxic Spills Two recent chemical spills have forced Chinese officials in two different regions to take emergency precautions to protect water supplies for millions of people in the latest examples of the environmental and public health threats posed by the nation's industrial pollution.

Scientist's House Raided Dr. Hwang Woo Suk, the disgraced stem cell scientist, apologized for falsifying data in his research. Prosecutors also raided his home and labs to investigate work that had propelled South Korea to the top of global stem cell research before it was found to be fraudulent.

Democrats Prod Nominee For Specifics at Hearing Democrats tried with increasing frustration to elicit more specific views from Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. about abortion and other topics and sought to build a case against his nomination to the Supreme Court by raising questions about his character and consistency.

A Tough Fight for DeLay Representative Tom DeLay, Republican of Texas, finds himself in the toughest re-election campaign of his 11-term House career, in part because of the Congressional redistricting scheme he spearheaded.

New Orleans Plan Draws Fire Residents of the city's most devastated neighborhoods responded with anger after the city's rebuilding commission unveiled its most contentious proposal: giving neighborhoods in low-lying parts of the city from four months to a year to prove they should not be bulldozed.

Court Access for Condemned An argument before the Supreme Court in a 20-year-old murder case suggested that the court might be willing to open the door a bit wider to death row inmates seeking access to federal court to present plausible but belated claims of innocence.

Bishop Says He Was Abused Saying he had been sexually abused as a teenage seminarian, a Roman Catholic Bishop became the highest-ranking member of the church to endorse legislation in various states that would loosen the statute of limitations on lawsuits relating to sexual abuse by clergy members.

Author Made Up Details of Life James Frey, the author of ''A Million Little Pieces,'' which has been the best-selling book in the country since Oprah Winfrey selected it last fall for her television book club, acknowledged that he had made up details of his life on ''Larry King Live'' on CNN. But he maintained that what he believes is the essence of the book is true. Ms. Winfrey, in a telephone call to Mr. King's program, said she believed the book's underlying message was true, adding that she would continue to recommend it.

For Many Asians, America Means Pounds and Peril Asians, especially those from Far Eastern nations like China, Korea and Japan, are acutely susceptible to Type 2 diabetes, the most common form of the disease, a factor that is compounded by a sudden collision with and adaptation to the American diet.

New York Faces Voting Suit The Justice Department has threatened to sue New York State over its failure to modernize its voting system, saying the city ''is further behind'' every other state in the nation in complying with new guidelines stemming from the 2000 presidential election.

Golisano Considers Running Tom Golisano plans to announce by the end of January if he will run for governor of New York this year, but Republican leaders say they believe he will indeed seek their party's nomination.

Inquiry Into Girl's Death A 7-year-old Brooklyn girl was found beaten to death inside her home in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where evidence suggested she had been kept apart from her five siblings and kept bound to a chair in her room, a law enforcement official said.
Birgit Nilsson The Swedish soprano with a voice of impeccable trueness and impregnable stamina, she was 87.
Sidney E. Frank The businessman who concocted spectacularly successful marketing campaigns for Jägermeister liqueur and Grey Goose vodka, he was 86.

Johnson Raises Guidant Bid Johnson & Johnson reached a new agreement with Guidant, raising its bid to $23.2 billion and pre-empting a rival offer from Boston Scientific. But several people close to Boston Scientific suggested the company was planning a new offer.

China's Trade Surplus Grows China said its trade surplus with the rest of the world had tripled in 2005, to a record $102 billion, a figure that could reignite global trade frictions and step up pressure on the government to allow its currency to appreciate further.

Turnover at Morgan Stanley Morgan Stanley sustained its first high-level executive departures of the new year in a sign that the poaching that plagued the firm during its leadership struggle has flared up again.

Criticism of Realtors' Group The National Association of Realtors has come under fire from a broad range of critics who say the organization and its state and local affiliates have worked to smother competition.
Editorials: Judge Alito, in his own words; an incendiary threat in Iraq; drugs and racial discrimination. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert.
